species.hab: Dominant forest tree on well-drained, fertile soils throughout SjÃ¦lland. Prefers slightly acidic to calcareous ground.
feat: Smooth silver-grey bark that remains smooth even on old trees
Oval leaves 5â€“10 cm with wavy (not toothed) margins, silky-hairy when young
Buds long (15â€“20 mm), sharply pointed, cigar-shaped, copper-brown
Fruit: triangular nuts (beech mast) in pairs inside a spiny 4-valved husk
Dense canopy casting deep shade; little understorey
species.season: Leaves emerge pale green Aprilâ€“May, turn golden-copper in autumn. Dead leaves persist on young trees through winter (marcescence).

conf.d: Hornbeam has doubly serrate (toothed) leaf margins and a fluted/ridged trunk; beech has wavy-edged leaves and always-smooth bark.

species.hab: Mixed forests, hedgerows, parkland. Tolerates heavy clay. Very common across SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Deeply lobed leaves with 4â€“5 rounded lobe pairs; very short petiole (<5 mm)
Bark deeply fissured into rough vertical ridges on mature trees
Acorns on long stalks (peduncles) 3â€“7 cm â€” the key diagnostic
Clustered buds at twig tips, ovoid, orange-brown
Branches often gnarled; irregular crown on old specimens
species.season: Late to leaf out (May). Brown autumn leaves may persist on young trees. Acorns ripen Septemberâ€“October.

conf.d: Sessile oak has longer leaf stalks (1â€“2 cm) and acorns sitting directly on the twig without peduncles. Rarer on SjÃ¦lland.

species.hab: Pioneer species on sandy, acidic, or disturbed soils. Heathland edges, roadsides, open woodland.
feat: White papery bark peeling in horizontal strips; base becomes black and fissured with age
Small triangular-rhombic leaves (3â€“7 cm), doubly serrate margins
Twigs slender, pendulous (hanging), with small warty resin glands
Male catkins pendulous, 3â€“6 cm; female catkins smaller, upright then drooping
Light, airy crown â€” never dense shade
species.season: Among the first trees to leaf out in spring. Yellow autumn colour. Male catkins visible from autumn through winter.

conf.d: Downy birch has hairy (not warty) young twigs, more rounded leaves, greyer bark, and prefers wetter soils.

species.hab: Fertile moist soils; forests, hedgerows. Common but declining due to ash dieback (Hymenoscyphus fraxineus).
feat: Compound pinnate leaves with 7â€“13 leaflets, opposite arrangement on the twig
Distinctive jet-black buds â€” very reliable winter ID feature
Bark smooth and pale grey when young, developing shallow fissures with age
Winged seeds (keys) in dense hanging clusters, single-winged
Last native tree to leaf out in spring; first to drop leaves in autumn
species.season: Leafs out late May. Seeds persist into winter. Black buds are the best year-round ID.

conf.d: Rowan also has pinnate leaves but leaflets are smaller (3â€“6 cm), sharply toothed, alternate on branch; buds purple-grey and hairy, not black.

species.hab: Mixed deciduous forests on fertile soils. Also widely planted as a street and park tree.
feat: Heart-shaped leaves 3â€“8 cm with pointed tip and asymmetric base
Underside has characteristic orange-brown hair tufts in vein axils
Bark smooth grey when young, finely fissured with age
Fragrant yellowish flowers in clusters hanging from a wing-like bract (July)
Small round fruits (4â€“6 mm), thin-walled, without prominent ribs
species.season: Fragrant flowering in July attracts abundant insects. Leaves turn yellow in autumn.

conf.d: Larger leaves (6â€“15 cm), white hair tufts beneath (not orange-brown), and ribbed, thick-walled fruits.

species.hab: Wet ground: stream banks, bog margins, lakeshores, damp forest. Nitrogen-fixer.
feat: Rounded leaves 5â€“10 cm with a notched (retuse) apex â€” distinctive flat or indented leaf tip
Young leaves and buds are sticky (glutinous)
Small woody cone-like fruits (1â€“2 cm) persist year-round â€” key winter ID
Bark dark brown to blackish, fissured into small squares on mature trees
Male catkins purple-stalked, visible from autumn, opening before leaves
species.season: Catkins open Februaryâ€“March. Woody cones persist through winter. Always near water.

conf.d: Grey alder has pointed (not notched) leaf tips, grey bark, and grey-hairy leaf undersides. Less common on SjÃ¦lland.

species.hab: Forest edges, clearings, roadsides. Pioneer species. Spreads vigorously by root suckers.
feat: Rounded leaves 3â€“8 cm on very long, flattened petioles â€” leaves tremble in slightest breeze
Leaf margin with blunt rounded teeth (crenate)
Bark smooth greenish-grey; darker and furrowed at base with age
Long grey drooping catkins appear before leaves, Marchâ€“April
Often forms clonal stands from root suckers
species.season: Trembling leaves audible in summer. Catkins appear early spring. Good golden-yellow autumn colour.

conf.d: Grey poplar leaves are greyish-white and downy beneath. Often larger. Hybrid origin.

species.hab: Mixed forests, hedgerows, ravines. Prefers fertile moist soils. Declining due to Dutch elm disease.
feat: Large leaves 8â€“16 cm with markedly asymmetric base â€” one side extends further down petiole
Leaf surface very rough (sandpapery) with stiff hairs on upper side
Doubly serrate leaf margin
Winged seeds (samaras) with seed in centre of wing; appear before leaves
Buds dark brown, hairy; bark grey-brown, rough fissures
species.season: Flowers and fruits appear Marchâ€“April before leaves. Leaves turn yellow in autumn.

conf.d: Field elm has smaller, smoother, glossy leaves with less pronounced asymmetry. Suckering habit. Very rare on SjÃ¦lland.

species.hab: Widely planted forestry species. Not native to Denmark but naturalised. Traditional Danish Christmas tree.
feat: Needles short (1â€“2.5 cm), stiff, pointed, singly attached all around the twig
Twig rough with small woody pegs when needles removed â€” key diagnostic vs fir
Cones pendulous, large (10â€“18 cm), cylindrical, hanging down
Bark reddish-brown, thin, scaly
Regular conical crown with drooping side-branches
species.season: Evergreen. Light green new growth (candles) in May. Cones ripen autumn.

conf.d: Firs have flat needles with two white stripes beneath, smooth bark with resin blisters, and upright cones that disintegrate on the tree.

species.hab: Sandy soils, heathland, planted forests. Widely planted on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Needles in pairs, 3â€“7 cm long, twisted, blue-green
Upper bark distinctive orange-red, flaking in thin plates â€” visible from distance
Lower trunk bark grey-brown, deeply fissured
Small ovoid cones (3â€“7 cm), green ripening to grey-brown
Mature trees develop flat-topped or irregular crown, not conical
species.season: Evergreen. Orange upper bark visible year-round. Old needles shed in autumn (normal).

conf.d: Black pine has much longer needles (10â€“15 cm), stiffer, not twisted, darker green. Bark uniformly grey-brown without orange upper trunk.

species.hab: Planted in forests and parks. Native to the Alps, introduced to Denmark for forestry.
feat: Deciduous conifer â€” the only common conifer that loses needles in winter
Needles soft, light green, 2â€“4 cm, in rosette-like clusters of 30â€“40 on short shoots
Small upright cones (2â€“4 cm), ovoid, persisting on branches for years
Bark grey-brown developing deep fissures and pinkish inner bark
Crown conical when young, broader with age
species.season: Bright fresh green needles in spring; golden-yellow before falling Octoberâ€“November. Bare branches with small cones in winter diagnostic.

conf.d: Japanese larch has blue-green (glaucous) needles, slightly larger cones with recurved scale tips, reddish-brown twigs.

species.hab: Forests, parks, streets. Native to eastern Denmark including parts of SjÃ¦lland; also very widely planted.
feat: Leaves with 5 sharply pointed lobes, few large teeth, 10â€“15 cm wide
Milky sap when leaf petiole is broken â€” key diagnostic vs sycamore
Bright yellow-green flower clusters appear before leaves in April
Winged seed pairs (samaras) spread at obtuse angle (nearly 180Â°)
Bark grey, shallow interlacing ridges (not flaking)
species.season: Conspicuous yellow-green flowers April. Excellent yellow autumn colour. Samaras ripen autumn.

conf.d: Sycamore has blunter leaf lobes, coarser teeth, no milky sap from petiole, drooping flower clusters (not erect), samaras at more acute angle.

species.hab: Widely planted in parks, gardens, shelter belts. Naturalised, sometimes invasive. Not native to Denmark.
feat: Large 5-lobed leaves 10â€“25 cm wide, lobes with coarse irregular blunt teeth
No milky sap when petiole is broken (unlike Norway maple)
Bark grey, smooth when young, developing large flaking plates revealing pink-brown inner bark
Pendulous flower racemes Aprilâ€“May, after leaf emergence
Winged seed pairs at acute angle (approx. 60â€“90Â°)
species.season: Leaves emerge reddish. Often just turns brown in autumn. Flaking bark diagnostic on mature trees.

conf.d: Norway maple has sharply pointed lobes, milky sap from petiole, erect yellow-green flower clusters before leaves, widely spread samaras.

species.hab: Parks, avenues, gardens. Native to the Balkans, widely planted across Denmark.
feat: Large palmate compound leaves with 5â€“7 leaflets radiating from single point, leaflets 10â€“25 cm
Very large sticky buds â€” among the most recognisable winter features of any tree
Upright conical flower candles in May, white with pink/yellow markings
Fruit: spiny green husk containing 1â€“2 glossy brown conkers
Bark grey-brown, scaly, peeling in irregular plates
species.season: Leaf out and flowering May. Conkers fall Septemberâ€“October. Sticky buds key winter ID. Often shows leaf miner damage by midsummer.

conf.d: Red horse chestnut has pink-red flowers, smaller leaves. Hybrid, less commonly planted.

species.hab: Mixed deciduous forests, hedgerows. Native to eastern Denmark including SjÃ¦lland. Also widely planted as hedging.
feat: Oval leaves 5â€“10 cm with prominent parallel veins, doubly serrate margins
Bark smooth grey with distinctive fluted (muscular) trunk â€” key diagnostic
Fruit: small nutlet attached to three-lobed leafy bract, in hanging clusters
Buds slender, appressed to twig, shorter than beech buds
Leaves strongly resemble beech but always have clear serrations
species.season: Retains dead brown leaves through winter (marcescence). Fruits ripen autumn. Fluted trunk visible year-round.

conf.d: Beech has smooth (never fluted) trunk, wavy (not serrate) leaf margins, longer sharper buds. Beech nuts triangular in spiny husk, not winged.

species.hab: Forest edges, clearings, rocky ground, heathland, gardens. Tolerates poor acidic soils.
feat: Pinnate leaves with 9â€“15 small leaflets (3â€“6 cm each), sharply toothed
Alternate leaf arrangement (vs opposite in ash)
Dense clusters of creamy-white flowers Mayâ€“June
Bright red-orange berry clusters Augustâ€“September â€” very conspicuous
Bark smooth shiny grey-silver; buds purple-grey with grey hairs
species.season: Red berries from August. Flowers Mayâ€“June. Good yellow-red autumn colour.

conf.d: Ash has fewer, larger leaflets (5â€“12 cm), opposite arrangement, black buds, winged seeds not berries. Much larger tree.

species.hab: Mixed forests, hedgerows, forest edges on fertile soils. Common on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Bark reddish-brown with prominent horizontal lenticels â€” peels in horizontal strips
Leaves oval 6â€“15 cm, serrate margins; two red glands at petiole top
White flowers in clusters of 2â€“6 on long stalks, with leaves, Aprilâ€“May
Small red to dark red cherries Juneâ€“July
Autumn colour often excellent â€” red, orange, yellow
species.season: White blossom Aprilâ€“May. Cherries ripen Juneâ€“July. Distinctive bark year-round.

conf.d: Bird cherry has flowers in elongated racemes (not short clusters), smaller leaves, grey-brown bark without prominent lenticels, unpleasant bark smell.

species.hab: Moist woodlands, stream banks, hedgerows. Prefers damp fertile soils.
feat: Flowers in elongated drooping racemes (10â€“15 cm) â€” key diagnostic; May
Small black bitter cherries in drooping strings
Bark smooth dark grey-brown; unpleasant smell when scratched
Leaves elliptic 6â€“10 cm, finely toothed, dull upper surface
Buds conical, appressed, dark brown
species.season: Fragrant white blossom in May. Black fruit Julyâ€“August, quickly eaten by birds.

conf.d: Wild cherry has flowers in short clusters (not racemes), reddish bark with horizontal bands, red (not black) larger cherries.

species.hab: Forest edges, hedgerows, waste ground. Pioneer species. Common throughout SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Leaves broadly elliptic to almost round (5â€“10 cm), wrinkled surface, grey woolly underside
Large silvery-furry catkins before leaves in March â€” pussy willows
Male catkins turn bright yellow with pollen; female catkins greener
Twigs stout; bark grey-brown with diamond-shaped fissures
Stipules at leaf base (small ear-shaped appendages)
species.season: Among earliest flowering (March). Catkins important early nectar source. Grey woolly leaf undersides all summer.

conf.d: Grey willow has narrower leaves, raised ridges under the bark when stripped, and grows in wetter habitats. Often hybridises.

species.hab: Hedgerows, scrub, forest edges, pastures. Extremely common. Often planted as hedging.
feat: Sharp thorns (1â€“1.5 cm) on branches â€” key feature
Leaves deeply lobed (3â€“7 lobes), 2â€“4 cm, lobes cut more than halfway to midrib
Dense clusters of white (sometimes pink) flowers with a single style, Mayâ€“June
Dark red haws (berries) with a single stone, Septemberâ€“October
Bark grey-brown, developing orange-brown fissures; gnarled twisted form
species.season: Abundant white may blossom in May. Red haws from September. Thorns and gnarled form year-round.

conf.d: Midland hawthorn has shallower leaf lobes (less than halfway to midrib), 2â€“3 styles per flower, 2â€“3 stones per haw.

species.hab: Hedgerows, woodland edges, waste ground, gardens, near buildings. Extremely common everywhere on SjÃ¦lland. Nitrogen-loving, often near old habitation.
feat: Compound pinnate leaves with 5â€“7 leaflets, toothed margins, opposite arrangement
Flat-topped creamy-white flower heads (corymbs) 10â€“25 cm across, fragrant
Clusters of small glossy black-purple berries drooping in autumn
Bark grey-brown, deeply furrowed and corky on old stems
Stems have soft white pith when cut â€” distinctive cross-section
species.season: Flowers June (elderflower cordial season). Berries ripen Augustâ€“September. Unpleasant smell from crushed leaves.

conf.d: Red elder has red berries in rounded (not flat) clusters, and conical flower heads. Much rarer in Denmark.

species.hab: Woodland understorey, hedgerows, scrub on fertile soils. Very common. Often coppiced historically.
feat: Rounded leaves 6â€“12 cm with double-serrate margin, soft-hairy, short-pointed tip
Long pendulous yellow male catkins (lambs' tails) in Februaryâ€“March â€” very early
Tiny red female flowers: only the crimson stigmas protrude from the bud
Hazelnuts in leafy involucre (husk), ripening Septemberâ€“October
Multi-stemmed from base (coppice form); bark smooth brown
species.season: Male catkins Januaryâ€“March are earliest sign of spring. Nuts ripen September. Leaves turn yellow in autumn.

conf.d: Filbert has a longer husk completely enclosing the nut. Planted, not wild in Denmark.

species.hab: Hedgerows, scrub, woodland edges, coastal slopes. Forms dense thickets. Very common throughout SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Dense mass of sharp thorns on dark blackish-brown twigs â€” impenetrable thickets
Small white 5-petalled flowers appearing before leaves in Marchâ€“April
Blue-black sloe berries with grey bloom, 1â€“1.5 cm, very astringent
Small leaves 2â€“4 cm, ovate, finely toothed
Spreads aggressively by root suckers
species.season: White blossom Marchâ€“April (before hawthorn). Sloes ripen Octoberâ€“November, traditionally picked after first frost.

conf.d: Hawthorn has lobed (not simple) leaves, red (not blue-black) berries, and flowers after leaves emerge. Thorns are less dense.

species.hab: Hedgerows, scrub, woodland edges, roadsides. Very common throughout SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Arching stems with curved (hooked) thorns
Compound pinnate leaves with 5â€“7 toothed leaflets
Pink or white 5-petalled flowers 4â€“5 cm, fragrant, Juneâ€“July
Bright red-orange rosehips 1.5â€“2 cm, ovoid, in autumn
Scrambling habit, often climbing through other shrubs
species.season: Flowers Juneâ€“July. Rosehips ripen September, persist into winter. Important bird food.

conf.d: Rosa rugosa has wrinkled (rugose) dark green leaves, much larger flowers (6â€“9 cm), and large flattened globe-shaped hips. Coastal, invasive.

species.hab: Hedgerows, moist woodland edges, stream banks. Fairly common on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Leaves 3â€“5-lobed resembling maple leaves, opposite arrangement
Flat flower heads with large showy sterile outer flowers ringing small fertile inner flowers
Translucent red berries in drooping clusters, persisting into winter
Bark grey-brown, smooth; twigs angled
Good autumn colour â€” purplish red
species.season: Flowers Mayâ€“June. Red berries from August, very conspicuous in winter. Leaves turn red-purple in autumn.

conf.d: The garden cultivar Snowball has all-sterile spherical flower heads (no small fertile flowers). Very commonly planted.

species.hab: Woodland understorey, hedgerows, gardens. Tolerates deep shade. Common on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Evergreen leathery leaves with sharp spiny margins â€” unmistakable
Leaves on upper branches often lose spines and become smooth-edged
Bright red berries in clusters (on female trees only), winter
Bark smooth grey-green
Small white 4-petalled flowers, inconspicuous, Mayâ€“June
species.season: Evergreen â€” conspicuous in winter when deciduous trees are bare. Red berries November onwards. Traditional Christmas decoration.

species.hab: Woodland edges, hedgerows, waste ground, gardens, roadsides. Extremely common everywhere.
feat: Arching thorny stems (canes) rooting at tips where they touch ground
Compound palmate leaves with 3â€“5 toothed leaflets, prickly stalks
White or pink 5-petalled flowers 2â€“3 cm in clusters
Blackberries: aggregate fruit green â†’ red â†’ glossy black when ripe
Semi-evergreen â€” old leaves persist through mild winters
species.season: Flowers Juneâ€“August. Blackberries ripen Augustâ€“September. Thorny thickets visible year-round.

conf.d: Raspberry has white-felted leaf undersides, fruit separates from core when picked (blackberry doesn't), fewer thorns.

species.hab: Coastal dunes, sea cliffs, planted along roads and in parks. Common on SjÃ¦lland coasts.
feat: Narrow silvery-grey leaves 3â€“8 cm, resembling willow leaves
Dense masses of bright orange berries clustered tightly on branches (female plants)
Branches with sharp thorns
Bark dark brown, rough; suckering habit forms dense thickets
Silvery scales on leaves and young twigs
species.season: Orange berries Augustâ€“March, very conspicuous in autumn/winter. Flowers inconspicuous, before leaves in Marchâ€“April.

species.hab: Coastal dunes, roadsides, waste ground. Invasive alien species. Very common on SjÃ¦lland coasts.
feat: Large showy flowers 6â€“9 cm, deep pink (sometimes white), very fragrant
Leaves with deeply wrinkled (rugose) surface â€” distinctive texture
Large flattened globe-shaped rosehips 2â€“3 cm, turning red
Dense thorny stems with many fine prickles
Spreads aggressively by root suckers â€” forms dense stands
species.season: Flowers Juneâ€“September (long season). Large hips ripen August onwards. Invasive â€” being actively managed on coasts.

conf.d: Dog rose has smooth leaves, smaller flowers (4â€“5 cm), smaller ovoid hips, and an arching (not suckering) growth habit.

species.hab: Deciduous woodland floors, hedgebanks. Dominant spring flower of Danish forests. Indicator of ancient woodland.
feat: Single white flower (sometimes pink-tinged) on slender stem, 2â€“4 cm across
6â€“7 petal-like tepals, no true petals
Three deeply divided palmate leaves in a whorl partway up stem
Spreads by creeping rhizomes â€” forms vast carpets
Entire plant dies back by June
species.season: Flowers Marchâ€“May, often in vast white carpets on the forest floor. Completely absent by midsummer.

conf.d: Yellow anemone has bright yellow flowers and is much less common. Sometimes grows alongside wood anemone.

species.hab: Deciduous woodland, especially on calcareous or clay soils. Less common than wood anemone but locally abundant on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Bright yellow flowers 1.5â€“2 cm across, usually 5 tepals
Palmate leaves similar to wood anemone but often in pairs
Shorter-stalked than wood anemone
Spreads by rhizomes but less aggressively
species.season: Flowers Marchâ€“May, slightly later than wood anemone. Often grows in mixed carpets with A. nemorosa.

conf.d: Lesser celandine has glossy heart-shaped basal leaves, 8â€“12 narrow petals, and prefers damper ground.

species.hab: Moist deciduous woodland, stream banks, hedgerows. Locally abundant on SjÃ¦lland, forming dense colonies.
feat: Strong garlic smell â€” diagnostic even before seeing the plant
Broad elliptic bright green leaves 2â€“3 per plant, from a bulb
White star-shaped flowers in rounded umbels on triangular stems
Leaves emerge Januaryâ€“February, well before flowers
Forms dense carpets that exclude other plants
species.season: Leaves Januaryâ€“March. Flowers Aprilâ€“June. Strong garlic smell from February. Dies back by July.

conf.d: Lily of the valley has similar-looking leaves but with NO garlic smell, bell-shaped flowers, and red berries. Toxic â€” important distinction for foragers.

species.hab: Woodland, hedgebanks, stream banks, damp grassland. Very common throughout SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Glossy bright yellow flowers with 8â€“12 narrow petals, 2â€“3 cm across
Heart-shaped to kidney-shaped glossy dark green basal leaves
Low-growing, spreading in patches
Small bulbils sometimes form in leaf axils
Flowers open only in sunshine, close in dull weather
species.season: One of the earliest spring flowers: Februaryâ€“May. Carpets of yellow on woodland floor and banks. Dies back by June.

conf.d: Creeping buttercup has 5 petals (not 8â€“12), deeply lobed leaves (not heart-shaped), and flowers later in summer.

species.hab: Woodland floors, shady banks, among tree roots. Common in older forests on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Shamrock-like trifoliate leaves that fold down at night or in rain
Delicate white flowers with lilac veins, 5 petals, 1 cm across
Leaves have a pleasantly sour taste (oxalic acid)
Creeping rhizome; forms small patches in deep shade
Seed capsules spring open explosively
species.season: Flowers Aprilâ€“June. Leaves present Marchâ€“October. Folds leaves in bright sun and at night.

conf.d: White clover has similar trifoliate leaves but with white chevron markings, round flower heads (not single flowers), and grows in open grassland not shade.

species.hab: Dry to mesic deciduous woodland, especially beech and oak. Locally common on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Two broad elliptic basal leaves per shoot, parallel-veined
One-sided raceme of small white bell-shaped fragrant flowers
Red berries in autumn â€” all parts of plant toxic
Spreads by rhizomes forming extensive colonies
Sweet distinctive fragrance
species.season: Flowers Mayâ€“June. Red berries Augustâ€“September. TOXIC â€” do not confuse with ramsons when foraging.

conf.d: Ramsons has strong garlic smell (lily of the valley has none), star-shaped flowers in umbels, and is edible. Critical distinction.

species.hab: Ancient deciduous woodland on calcareous or fertile soils. Common indicator of old woodland on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Opposite pairs of dark green, toothed, elliptic leaves on unbranched stems
Tiny inconspicuous green flowers on spikes â€” dioecious (separate male/female plants)
Forms dense carpets on the woodland floor
Mildly toxic â€” unpleasant smell when crushed
No basal rosette â€” stems emerge straight from rhizome
species.season: Flowers Februaryâ€“April. Leaves persist until autumn. One of the first woodland herbs to emerge.

conf.d: Nettles have stinging hairs, serrate (not crenate) leaves, and grow in more disturbed/nutrient-rich habitats.

species.hab: Beech and oak woodland on fertile soils. Common on SjÃ¦lland. Traditional Waldmeister flavouring.
feat: Whorls of 6â€“8 narrow leaves up the square stem â€” very distinctive arrangement
Small white 4-petalled star-shaped flowers in loose clusters
Sweet hay/vanilla scent when dried (coumarin)
Creeping rhizomes forming extensive patches
Fruits covered in tiny hooked bristles
species.season: Flowers Mayâ€“June. Sweet smell strongest when dried. Leaves in whorls distinctive all season.

conf.d: Cleavers has backward-pointing hooks on stems and leaves (sticky), scrambling habit, and grows in hedgerows/waste ground not woodland.

species.hab: Lawns, meadows, roadsides, waste ground, gardens â€” everywhere. The most recognisable wildflower in Denmark.
feat: Rosette of deeply toothed (dandelion-tooth) basal leaves
Single bright yellow composite flower head on hollow leafless stalk
White spherical seed head (clock) â€” parachute-like pappus on each seed
Milky white latex when stem or leaf is broken
Deep taproot, difficult to fully remove
species.season: Main flowering Aprilâ€“June but can flower any month. Seed clocks conspicuous. Leaves present year-round.

conf.d: Cat's ear has branched flower stems (not single), hairy leaves, and scales among the florets. Less deeply toothed leaves.

species.hab: Lawns, short grassland, parks, playing fields. Ubiquitous across SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Small composite flower: white ray florets (often pink-tipped) around yellow disc
Flat rosette of spoon-shaped leaves at ground level
Single flower head per leafless stalk, 1.5â€“3 cm across
Flowers close at night and in rain
Extremely tolerant of mowing â€” thrives in short turf
species.season: Flowers almost year-round but peak Marchâ€“October. Present in every mowed lawn.

species.hab: Lawns, meadows, roadsides, pastures. Nitrogen-fixer. Extremely common everywhere.
feat: Trifoliate leaves with white V-shaped chevron markings on each leaflet
White to pinkish-white round flower heads on long stalks above leaves
Creeping stems (stolons) root at nodes
Important pollinator plant â€” attracts abundant bees
Rare 4-leaf clovers occur at roughly 1 in 5,000
species.season: Flowers Mayâ€“October. Leaves present year-round in mild winters.

conf.d: Red clover has pink-purple flower heads, no white leaf markings, and more upright habit with hairy stems.

species.hab: Meadows, roadsides, field margins, pastures. Very common throughout SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Trifoliate leaves often with faint pale V marking, leaflets broader than white clover
Pink to purple-red rounded flower heads, 2â€“3 cm across, sessile above leaf pair
More upright growth than white clover, hairy stems
Nitrogen-fixing root nodules
species.season: Flowers Mayâ€“September. Important meadow plant and pollinator resource.

conf.d: White clover has white flowers on long stalks, prominent white chevrons on leaves, and creeping (not upright) growth.

species.hab: Meadows, pastures, roadsides, damp grassland. Very common on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Glossy bright yellow 5-petalled flowers, 2 cm across
Deeply divided palmate basal leaves with 3â€“7 lobes
Tall branching stems, hairy
Flower petals reflect UV light and have a waxy sheen (butter test under chin)
Mildly toxic to livestock
species.season: Flowers Mayâ€“July. Abundant in uncut meadows. The quintessential Danish summer meadow flower.

conf.d: Creeping buttercup has stolons, more triangular leaves with a distinctly stalked middle lobe, and prefers wetter/disturbed ground.

species.hab: Meadows, roadsides, railway embankments, dry grassland. Common on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Large daisy-like flower heads 3â€“6 cm across: white rays around yellow disc
Spoon-shaped toothed basal leaves; stem leaves narrow and clasping
Single flower head per stem (occasionally branched)
Tough wiry stems
species.season: Flowers Juneâ€“August. Conspicuous in unmown meadows and road verges.

conf.d: Common daisy is much smaller (1.5â€“3 cm heads), ground-hugging rosette only, no stem leaves.

species.hab: Meadows, roadsides, lawns, dry grassland, waste ground. Very common everywhere.
feat: Feathery, finely divided leaves â€” fernlike, aromatic when crushed
Flat-topped clusters (corymbs) of tiny white (sometimes pink) flower heads
Tough upright stems, often in clumps
Distinctive aromatic/medicinal smell
species.season: Flowers Juneâ€“September. Aromatic feathery leaves present from spring. Persistent dead stems in winter.

species.hab: Hedgerows, roadsides, woodland edges, meadow margins. Extremely common Mayâ€“June on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Finely divided fernlike leaves (2â€“3 times pinnate)
White flowers in compound umbels (umbrella-shaped clusters)
Hollow furrowed stems, slightly hairy, not spotted
First of the large white umbellifers to flower each year
Fruit small, smooth, elongated
species.season: Dominates road verges and hedgerows Mayâ€“June with white foam of flowers. Dies back by late summer.

conf.d: Hogweed is much larger, has broader roughly lobed leaves (not finely divided), and hairy stems. Later flowering.
Giant hogweed grows 3â€“5 m tall, has red-spotted stems 5â€“10 cm thick, and causes severe skin burns. DANGEROUS â€” report sightings.

species.hab: Roadsides, hedgerows, meadow margins, woodland edges. Very common on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Very large roughly lobed pinnate leaves, hairy, up to 60 cm
Large white compound umbels up to 20 cm across
Thick hollow hairy stem (not red-spotted like giant hogweed)
Outer flowers of umbel have enlarged unequal petals
Can cause mild phototoxic skin reaction in sensitive individuals
species.season: Flowers Juneâ€“September. Tall and conspicuous along roadsides in summer.

conf.d: Giant hogweed is 3â€“5 m tall, has red-spotted stems 5â€“10 cm diameter, and causes SEVERE phototoxic burns. Report sightings to the kommune.
Cow parsley is smaller, earlier flowering, with finely divided (not broad-lobed) leaves.

species.hab: River banks, roadsides, waste ground. Invasive. Present on SjÃ¦lland â€” actively controlled by municipalities.
feat: Enormous â€” 3â€“5 metres tall, impossible to miss when mature
Red/purple-spotted stems 5â€“10 cm diameter, bristly hairs
Massive leaves up to 1â€“1.5 m across, deeply lobed
Huge white umbels up to 80 cm across
DANGEROUS: sap causes severe phototoxic burns (blistering with sun exposure)
species.season: Grows rapidly in spring, flowers Juneâ€“July. DO NOT TOUCH. Report locations to local authority.

conf.d: Common hogweed is much smaller (under 2 m), has no red spots on stems, and causes only mild reactions.

species.hab: Hedgerows, woodland edges, waste ground, gardens â€” wherever soil is nitrogen-rich. Ubiquitous.
feat: Opposite pairs of heart-shaped, sharply toothed leaves
Entire plant covered in stinging hairs â€” painful on contact
Tiny green-brown flowers in drooping catkin-like clusters from leaf axils
Stems square in cross-section
Spreads by creeping yellow rhizomes â€” forms dense patches
species.season: Grows Aprilâ€“October. Young shoots edible (cooked). Important food plant for butterfly larvae. Stings all season.

conf.d: Dead-nettle has similar-looking leaves but NO stinging hairs, and showy white hooded flowers. Member of mint family, not nettle family.

species.hab: Woodland clearings, roadsides, railway embankments, waste ground, fire sites. Common on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Tall spikes of pink-purple 4-petalled flowers
Narrow willowlike alternate leaves
Long seed pods split to release masses of cottony seeds
Forms dense stands via rhizome spreading
Pioneer of disturbed ground (historically called fireweed)
species.season: Flowers Juneâ€“August. Cotton-like seed dispersal September. Very conspicuous pink stands along roads and railways.

species.hab: Meadows, lawns, roadsides, paths, waste ground. Extremely common everywhere.
feat: Basal rosette of narrow lance-shaped ribbed leaves with 3â€“5 parallel veins
Dense oval-cylindrical brown flower heads on long leafless furrowed stalks
Ring of white stamens appears around the head during flowering
Very tough â€” survives heavy trampling
Used in traditional Danish herbal medicine
species.season: Flowers Mayâ€“September. Leaves present year-round. The white stamen ring is distinctive.

conf.d: Broad-leaved plantain has wide oval leaves flat to the ground and elongated cylindrical flower spikes.

species.hab: Fields, roadsides, meadows, waste ground. Very common agricultural weed on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Pinkish-purple thistle flower heads in loose clusters, 1.5â€“2.5 cm
Spiny-toothed wavy-edged leaves, not as deeply lobed as other thistles
Spreads aggressively by creeping roots â€” forms large patches
Stems without spiny wings (unlike spear thistle)
Dioecious â€” separate male and female plants
species.season: Flowers Julyâ€“September. Attracts abundant butterflies and bees. Thistledown (pappose seeds) disperses autumn.

conf.d: Spear thistle has larger flower heads, deeply lobed very spiny leaves, and spiny winged stems. Biennial, not creeping.

species.hab: Gardens, hedgerows, woodland edges, waste ground. Extremely common and persistent weed throughout SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Leaves divided into 3 groups of 3 leaflets (ternate) â€” distinctive
White flowers in compound umbels similar to cow parsley but smaller
Triangular cross-section stem (unique among umbellifer weeds)
Spreads relentlessly by white creeping rhizomes
Young leaves edible and traditionally eaten in spring
species.season: Leaves Marchâ€“November. Flowers Juneâ€“July. The gardener's nemesis â€” almost impossible to eradicate.

conf.d: Cow parsley has much more finely divided fernlike leaves, flowers earlier, and grows taller. Not a persistent garden weed.

species.hab: Roadsides, waste ground, river banks, field margins. Common on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Button-like bright yellow flower heads in flat-topped clusters, no ray florets
Deeply pinnately divided leaves, dark green, aromatic
Strong medicinal/camphorous smell when crushed
Stiff upright stems in clumps
species.season: Flowers Julyâ€“September. Distinctive yellow button clusters along roadsides. Persistent dried stems in winter.

species.hab: Waste ground, river banks, roadsides, railways, gardens. Highly invasive. Present across SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Tall bamboo-like hollow stems with distinct nodes, green with red-purple speckling
Large shield-shaped leaves with straight-cut base, 10â€“15 cm
Drooping clusters of tiny creamy-white flowers from leaf axils
Dies back to ground in winter â€” dead canes persist as brown hollow stems
Spreads by rhizome fragments â€” even tiny pieces regenerate
species.season: Grows rapidly Aprilâ€“June, reaching 2â€“3 m. Flowers Augustâ€“October. INVASIVE â€” do not cut or move soil containing roots.

conf.d: Giant knotweed has much larger leaves (up to 40 cm) with heart-shaped base. Even rarer but equally invasive.

species.hab: Lake margins, river banks, marshes, ditches, coastal wetlands. Dominant in Danish wetlands across SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Tall grass-like stems with large feathery purple-brown plume-like flower heads
Long flat leaves 1â€“3 cm wide, grey-green, with ligule of hairs
Dense stands formed by creeping rhizomes
Hollow stems used traditionally for thatching (tagrÃ¸r)
Rustling/swaying sound in wind â€” characteristic of Danish lakesides
species.season: Plumes develop Julyâ€“September, persist as golden-brown through winter. Dried reed beds are distinctive winter landscape.

species.hab: Shallow standing water, pond margins, ditches, marshes. Common on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Distinctive brown cigar-shaped seed head on tall straight stem â€” unmistakable
Long flat sword-like grey-green leaves up to 2 cm wide
Male flowers above female on same spike; male part falls off after pollinating
Seed head eventually bursts into cottony mass
Grows in water up to 80 cm deep
species.season: Brown seed heads from July, persisting into winter. Leaves emerge May. The seed heads are one of nature's most recognisable shapes.

conf.d: Lesser bulrush has narrower leaves (<1 cm), and a visible gap between male and female parts of the seed head.

species.hab: Stream banks, pond margins, ditches, marshes, wet meadows. Common on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Bright yellow iris flowers 7â€“10 cm across with 3 large drooping falls and 3 erect standards
Sword-shaped erect grey-green leaves forming fan-like clumps
Thick creeping rhizome
Seed pods large, cylindrical, splitting to show orange-brown seeds
All parts mildly toxic
species.season: Flowers Mayâ€“July. Very conspicuous yellow patches along waterways. Seed pods persist into autumn.

species.hab: Wet meadows, stream banks, ditches, damp woodland edges. Common on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Dense frothy clusters of tiny creamy-white fragrant flowers
Pinnate leaves with large terminal leaflet, dark green above, white-felted beneath
Sweet almond-honey fragrance â€” historically used to flavour mead (mjÃ¸d)
Red-tinged stems
Source of salicylic acid â€” the original inspiration for aspirin
species.season: Flowers Juneâ€“August. Sweet fragrance carries across damp meadows. Persistent red stems into winter.

species.hab: Stream banks, lake margins, wet meadows, ditches. Common on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Tall spikes of vivid pink-purple flowers â€” very showy
Narrow lance-shaped opposite or whorled leaves, unstalked
Square stems with 4 ridges
Flowers have 6 crinkled petals
Three different flower forms (tristylous) â€” unique reproductive system
species.season: Flowers Juneâ€“September. Among the showiest native wetland flowers. Conspicuous purple stands along waterways.

species.hab: Wet meadows, stream margins, marshes, damp woodland. Common on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Glossy bright yellow flowers 2â€“5 cm across, 5 petal-like sepals (no true petals)
Large kidney-shaped to heart-shaped glossy dark green basal leaves
Hollow stems
One of the first wetland flowers of spring
Mildly toxic
species.season: Flowers Marchâ€“May. Early spring golden-yellow patches in wet areas. Leaves persist into summer.

conf.d: Lesser celandine has many narrow petals (8â€“12), smaller heart-shaped leaves, and grows in drier woodland as well as damp areas.

species.hab: Heathland, moors, open acidic woodland, sand dunes. Dominant on heaths of western and central SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Low evergreen shrub with tiny scale-like leaves in 4 rows along stems
Masses of small pink-purple bell-like flowers in one-sided spikes
Woody stems at base
Flowers have 4 petal-like calyx lobes hiding tiny petals
Supports distinctive heathland ecosystem
species.season: Flowers Augustâ€“September â€” heathland turns purple. Evergreen foliage year-round.

conf.d: Cross-leaved heath has needle-like leaves in whorls of 4 forming crosses, larger urn-shaped pink flowers in terminal clusters, and prefers wetter ground.

species.hab: Wet heathland, bog margins, moist acidic ground. Common on wetter heath areas of SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Needle-like grey-green leaves in whorls of 4 forming distinct crosses when viewed from above
Drooping clusters of pink urn-shaped flowers at stem tips
Stems hairy with glandular hairs
Evergreen dwarf shrub
Indicator of wet acidic conditions
species.season: Flowers Juneâ€“September. Leaves in cross arrangement visible year-round.

conf.d: Heather has tiny scale-like leaves (not needle-like), smaller flowers in elongated spikes (not terminal clusters), and prefers drier ground.

species.hab: Heathland, acidic woodland understorey, forest clearings. Common in conifer plantations and on heaths on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Low deciduous shrub with bright green finely toothed oval leaves
Angular green stems (winged/ridged)
Small pink-green urn-shaped flowers, nodding
Blue-black edible berries with purple juice that stains fingers and teeth
Spreads by creeping rhizomes
species.season: Flowers Aprilâ€“June. Berries ripen Julyâ€“August. Leaves turn red in autumn before falling.

conf.d: Bog bilberry has bluish-grey untoothed leaves, round stems (not ridged), and grows on wetter boggy ground.

species.hab: Woodland clearings, heathland, hillsides, sandy soils. Very common and often dominant on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Very large fronds (up to 2 m), broadly triangular outline, 3 times pinnate
Single frond per stem arising from underground rhizome â€” not clump-forming
Fronds emerge as curled fiddleheads in spring
Frond edges roll under, covering spore-producing sori
Spreads by deep extensive rhizomes â€” can dominate large areas
species.season: Fronds emerge May, fully unfurled by June. Turn golden-brown in autumn. Dead brown fronds persist into winter.

conf.d: Male fern forms shuttlecock clumps from a central crown, with narrower oblong fronds. Does not spread by rhizome.

species.hab: Woodland, hedgebanks, shady walls, rocky ground. Very common on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Shuttlecock-shaped clump of fronds from a central crown (not spreading)
Fronds lance-shaped, 2 times pinnate, with rounded pinnule tips
Scales on the stipe (stem) â€” golden-brown, conspicuous
Round sori (spore clusters) with kidney-shaped cover (indusium)
Semi-evergreen â€” some fronds persist through mild winters
species.season: New fiddleheads unfurl Aprilâ€“May. Fronds persist into winter in mild years. Golden-brown scales visible at base.

conf.d: Broad buckler-fern has more finely divided (3 times pinnate) dark green fronds with dark-centred scales on the stipe.

species.hab: Moist woodland, stream banks, shady damp ground. Common on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Graceful, finely divided fronds, 2â€“3 times pinnate â€” more delicate than male fern
Fronds pale to yellow-green, lance-shaped, tapering at both ends
Sori elongated or J-shaped (not round) â€” key distinction from male fern
Stipe with sparse pale scales
Deciduous â€” fronds die back completely in autumn
species.season: Fronds emerge late April, fully developed by June. Yellow-brown in autumn, dying back completely by November.

conf.d: Male fern is coarser, darker green, with round sori, heavier golden-brown scales, and more persistent fronds.

species.hab: On tree trunks, rocks, old walls, mossy banks. Epiphytic or on rocks. Common in old forests on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Simple once-pinnate fronds â€” much less divided than other common ferns
Oblong alternate pinnae (leaflets) with smooth margins
Evergreen â€” stays green through winter
Large round orange sori on underside without cover (indusium)
Creeping rhizome along tree trunks or rock surfaces, sweet-tasting
species.season: Evergreen â€” most conspicuous in winter when growing on bare deciduous trees. New fronds in summer.

species.hab: Parks, churchyards, woodland edges, gardens. Naturalised across SjÃ¦lland. Not native to Denmark.
feat: Single nodding white bell-shaped flower per stem
Three long white outer tepals, three shorter inner tepals with green markings
Two narrow grey-green basal leaves
Appears through snow in late winter â€” among the very first flowers
Spreads by bulb offsets forming dense clumps
species.season: Flowers Januaryâ€“March. The classic first sign of spring. Often in churchyards and old gardens where historically planted.

conf.d: Spring snowflake is larger, has 6 equal tepals each with a green dot, and flowers slightly later. Rare in Denmark.

species.hab: Parks, churchyards, gardens, woodland edges. Naturalised in Denmark. Very popular garden plant.
feat: Single bright yellow buttercup-like flower 2â€“3 cm sitting on a ruff of green bracts
Appears very early â€” often through snow alongside snowdrops
Round basal leaf divided into lobes, appearing after flowers
Low-growing, forming dense yellow carpets
Tuber (not bulb) underground
species.season: Flowers Februaryâ€“March. Often grows with snowdrops. One of the earliest flowers, hugely popular in Denmark.

conf.d: Lesser celandine has glossy heart-shaped leaves (not a ruff of bracts), 8â€“12 petals (not 5â€“8), and flowers slightly later.

species.hab: Parks, lawns, gardens, churchyards. Widely planted and naturalised across SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Cup-shaped flowers in purple, white, yellow, or striped, 3â€“5 cm
Three stamens with bright orange stigmas visible inside
Narrow grass-like leaves with white central stripe
Flowers open in sunshine, close in dull weather and at night
Grows from a corm (not bulb)
species.season: Flowers Februaryâ€“April. Mass plantings in parks (Kongens Have, Frederiksberg) spectacular. Leaves persist briefly after flowers.

conf.d: Autumn crocus flowers in Septemberâ€“October without leaves, has 6 stamens (not 3), and is highly toxic.

species.hab: Parks, gardens, churchyards, roadsides. Widely planted across SjÃ¦lland. Some naturalised populations.
feat: Trumpet-shaped central corona surrounded by 6 pale yellow tepals
Single flower per stem, nodding slightly to one side
Flat strap-shaped grey-green basal leaves
All parts toxic (especially bulb) â€” contains lycorine
Many cultivated varieties (large-cupped, double, etc.)
species.season: Flowers Marchâ€“April. The Easter flower (pÃ¥skelilje) in Denmark. Dies back by June.

species.hab: Parks, gardens, churchyards, grass verges. Widely planted, frequently naturalised on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Dense conical spike of small urn-shaped blue-violet flowers
Flowers resemble tiny bunches of grapes â€” hence the name
Narrow grass-like floppy basal leaves (often appear in autumn)
Pale white infertile flowers at spike tip
Spreads by bulb offsets and self-seeding
species.season: Flowers Marchâ€“May. Often carpets lawns in parks and churchyards. Leaves may appear in autumn months before flowering.

species.hab: Deciduous woodland, parks, gardens. Some naturalised populations in old parks on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: One-sided drooping raceme of violet-blue bell-shaped flowers
Narrow strap-shaped glossy basal leaves
Sweet fragrance
Flowers nod to one side â€” curved stem tip
White pollen (Spanish bluebell has blue pollen)
species.season: Flowers Aprilâ€“May. Can form blue carpets in woodland. Dies back by July.

conf.d: Spanish bluebell has flowers all around the stem (not one-sided), wider open bells, blue pollen, and broader leaves. More commonly planted in Denmark.

species.hab: Gardens, parks, hedgerows, old farmsteads. Extremely widely planted across Denmark. Often persists at abandoned houses.
feat: Large pyramidal panicles of fragrant 4-lobed tubular flowers, lilac-purple or white
Heart-shaped opposite leaves, smooth, entire margins
Multi-stemmed suckering habit
Grey-brown bark, smooth becoming slightly furrowed
Fruit a dry capsule, persisting into winter
species.season: Flowers late Mayâ€“June â€” the defining scent of Danish early summer. Suckers readily.

species.hab: Gardens, parks, hedgerows. One of the most commonly planted garden shrubs in Denmark.
feat: Masses of bright yellow 4-petalled flowers before leaves â€” unmistakable in spring
Opposite simple leaves with toothed margins, appearing after flowers
Arching growth habit
Hollow or chambered stems (pith)
No scent despite showy flowers
species.season: Flowers Marchâ€“April â€” one of the earliest and most conspicuous garden shrubs to flower. Unremarkable green shrub in summer.

species.hab: Gardens, waste ground, railway embankments, walls. Widely planted, increasingly naturalised on SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Long conical panicles (20â€“30 cm) of tiny fragrant purple flowers
Attracts masses of butterflies â€” lives up to its name
Opposite lance-shaped leaves, grey-green above, white-felted beneath
Fast-growing semi-evergreen; can colonise bare ground and walls
Self-seeds freely; considered mildly invasive in some areas
species.season: Flowers Julyâ€“September. Peak butterfly attraction. Can flower in first year from seed.

species.hab: Gardens, parks, churchyards as hedging. Extremely commonly planted across SjÃ¦lland. Increasingly naturalised in woodland.
feat: Large glossy evergreen leaves 10â€“20 cm, leathery, dark green
Upright racemes of small white fragrant flowers
Black cherry-like fruits in clusters
Leaves smell of almonds (cyanide) when crushed
Dense growth â€” popular for screening hedges
species.season: Flowers Aprilâ€“May. Evergreen â€” conspicuous in winter. Berries ripen dark by September. Increasingly problematic as an invasive in Danish woodlands.

conf.d: Bay laurel has smaller, aromatic leaves used in cooking, is not fully hardy in Denmark, and is rarely planted as hedging.

species.hab: Hedgerows, gardens, parks. Extremely commonly planted as hedging throughout Denmark.
feat: Small opposite oval leaves, semi-evergreen to evergreen
Clusters of small white fragrant flowers with 4 petals
Glossy black berries in clusters â€” mildly toxic
Dense twiggy growth, responds well to clipping
The classic Danish garden hedge plant
species.season: Flowers Juneâ€“July. Black berries autumnâ€“winter. Retains leaves in mild winters.

species.hab: Parks, gardens, hedgerows, naturalised in woodland edges. Widely planted and naturalised across SjÃ¦lland.
feat: Conspicuous white spongy berries 1â€“1.5 cm in clusters â€” persist into winter
Small oval opposite leaves, often slightly lobed on vigorous shoots
Tiny pink bell-shaped flowers, inconspicuous
Dense suckering growth forming thickets
Berries pop when squeezed â€” irresistible to children
species.season: White berries from September, persisting well into winter on bare stems. Flowers Juneâ€“August but easily overlooked.

species.hab: Parks, gardens, large estates, woodland. Widely planted on acidic soils. Can become invasive in woodland.
feat: Large evergreen leathery leaves 8â€“20 cm, glossy dark green, curling in cold weather
Showy clusters of large pink-purple funnel-shaped flowers
Dense spreading shrub, can form impenetrable thickets
Prefers acidic soils â€” won't grow on chalk
All parts toxic â€” even honey from the flowers
species.season: Flowers Mayâ€“June. Spectacular when in bloom. Evergreen â€” leaf curling in winter is diagnostic.
